1.text: In my first book, O Theophilus, I wrote about all that Jesus began to do and to teach,

2.text: until the day He was taken up to heaven, after giving instructions through the Holy Spirit to the apostles He had chosen.

3.text: After His suffering, He presented Himself to them with many convincing proofs that He was alive. He appeared to them over a span of forty days and spoke about the kingdom of God.

4.text: And while they were gathered together, He commanded them: “Do not leave Jerusalem, but wait for the gift the Father promised, which you have heard Me discuss.

5.text: For John baptized with water, but in a few days you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.”

6.text: So when they came together, they asked Him, “Lord, will You at this time restore the kingdom to Israel?”

7.text: Jesus replied, “It is not for you to know times or seasons that the Father has fixed by His own authority.

8.text: But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes upon you, and you will be My witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.”

9.text: After He had said this, they watched as He was taken up, and a cloud hid Him from their sight.

10.text: They were looking intently into the sky as He was going, when suddenly two men dressed in white stood beside them.

11.text: “Men of Galilee,” they said, “why do you stand here looking into the sky? This same Jesus, who has been taken from you into heaven, will come back in the same way you have seen Him go into heaven.”

12.text: Then they returned to Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives, which is near the city, a Sabbath day’s journey away.

13.text: When they arrived, they went to the upper room where they were staying: Peter and John, James and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, James son of Alphaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas son of James.

14.text: With one accord they all continued in prayer, along with the women and Mary the mother of Jesus, and with His brothers.

15.text: In those days Peter stood up among the brothers (a gathering of about a hundred and twenty) and said,

16.text: “Brothers, the Scripture had to be fulfilled that the Holy Spirit foretold through the mouth of David concerning Judas, who became a guide for those who arrested Jesus.

17.text: He was one of our number and shared in this ministry.”

18.text: (Now with the reward for his wickedness Judas bought a field; there he fell headlong and burst open in the middle, and all his intestines spilled out.

19.text: This became known to all who lived in Jerusalem, so they called that field in their own language Akeldama, that is, Field of Blood.)

20.text: “For it is written in the book of Psalms: ‘May his place be deserted; let there be no one to dwell in it,’ and, ‘May another take his position.’

21.text: Therefore it is necessary to choose one of the men who have accompanied us the whole time the Lord Jesus went in and out among us,

22.text: beginning from John’s baptism until the day Jesus was taken up from us. For one of these must become a witness with us of His resurrection.”

23.text: So they proposed two men: Joseph called Barsabbas (also known as Justus) and Matthias.

24.text: And they prayed, “Lord, You know everyone’s heart. Show us which of these two You have chosen

25.text: to take up this ministry and apostleship, which Judas abandoned to go to his rightful place.”

26.text: Then they cast lots, and the lot fell to Matthias. So he was added to the eleven apostles.

1.text: When the day of Pentecost came, they were all together in one place.

2.text: Suddenly a sound like a mighty rushing wind came from heaven and filled the whole house where they were sitting.

3.text: They saw tongues like flames of fire that separated and came to rest on each of them.

4.text: And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other tongues as the Spirit enabled them.

5.text: Now there were dwelling in Jerusalem God-fearing Jews from every nation under heaven.

6.text: And when this sound rang out, a crowd came together in bewilderment, because each one heard them speaking his own language.

7.text: Astounded and amazed, they asked, “Are not all these who are speaking Galileans?

8.text: How is it then that each of us hears them in his own native language?

9.text: Parthians, Medes, and Elamites; residents of Mesopotamia, Judea and Cappadocia, Pontus and Asia,

10.text: Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and the parts of Libya near Cyrene; visitors from Rome,

11.text: both Jews and converts to Judaism; Cretans and Arabs—we hear them declaring the wonders of God in our own tongues!”

12.text: Astounded and perplexed, they asked one another, “What does this mean?”

13.text: But others mocked them and said, “They are drunk on new wine!”

14.text: Then Peter stood up with the Eleven, lifted up his voice, and addressed the crowd: “Men of Judea and all who dwell in Jerusalem, let this be known to you, and listen carefully to my words.

15.text: These men are not drunk, as you suppose. It is only the third hour of the day!

16.text: No, this is what was spoken by the prophet Joel:

17.text: ‘In the last days, God says, I will pour out My Spirit on all people. Your sons and daughters will prophesy, your young men will see visions, your old men will dream dreams.

18.text: Even on My menservants and maidservants I will pour out My Spirit in those days, and they will prophesy.

19.text: I will show wonders in the heavens above and signs on the earth below, blood and fire and billows of smoke.

20.text: The sun will be turned to darkness, and the moon to blood, before the coming of the great and glorious Day of the Lord.

21.text: And everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.’

22.text: Men of Israel, listen to this message: Jesus of Nazareth was a man certified by God to you by miracles, wonders, and signs, which God did among you through Him, as you yourselves know.

23.text: He was delivered up by God’s set plan and foreknowledge, and you, by the hands of the lawless, put Him to death by nailing Him to the cross.

24.text: But God raised Him from the dead, releasing Him from the agony of death, because it was impossible for death to keep Him in its grip.

25.text: David says about Him: ‘I saw the Lord always before me; because He is at my right hand, I will not be shaken.

26.text: Therefore my heart is glad and my tongue rejoices; my body also will dwell in hope,

27.text: because You will not abandon my soul to Hades, nor will You let Your Holy One see decay.

28.text: You have made known to me the paths of life; You will fill me with joy in Your presence.’

29.text: Brothers, I can tell you with confidence that the patriarch David died and was buried, and his tomb is with us to this day.

30.text: But he was a prophet and knew that God had promised him on oath that He would place one of his descendants on his throne.

31.text: Foreseeing this, David spoke about the resurrection of the Christ, that He was not abandoned to Hades, nor did His body see decay.

32.text: God has raised this Jesus to life, to which we are all witnesses.

33.text: Exalted, then, to the right hand of God, He has received from the Father the promised Holy Spirit and has poured out what you now see and hear.

34.text: For David did not ascend into heaven, but he himself says: ‘The Lord said to my Lord, “Sit at My right hand

35.text: until I make Your enemies a footstool for Your feet.”’

36.text: Therefore let all Israel know with certainty that God has made this Jesus, whom you crucified, both Lord and Christ!”

37.text: When the people heard this, they were cut to the heart and asked Peter and the other apostles, “Brothers, what shall we do?”

38.text: Peter replied, “Repent and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.

39.text: This promise belongs to you and your children and to all who are far off—to all whom the Lord our God will call to Himself.”

40.text: With many other words he testified, and he urged them, “Be saved from this corrupt generation.”

41.text: Those who embraced his message were baptized, and about three thousand were added to the believers that day.

42.text: They devoted themselves to the apostles’ teaching and to the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and to prayer.

43.text: A sense of awe came over everyone, and the apostles performed many wonders and signs.

44.text: All the believers were together and had everything in common.

45.text: Selling their possessions and goods, they shared with anyone who was in need.

46.text: With one accord they continued to meet daily in the temple courts and to break bread from house to house, sharing their meals with gladness and sincerity of heart,

47.text: praising God and enjoying the favor of all the people. And the Lord added to their number daily those who were being saved.

1.text: One afternoon Peter and John were going up to the temple at the hour of prayer, the ninth hour.

2.text: And a man who was lame from birth was being carried to the temple gate called Beautiful, where he was put every day to beg from those entering the temple courts.

3.text: When he saw Peter and John about to enter, he asked them for money.

4.text: Peter looked directly at him, as did John. “Look at us!” said Peter.

5.text: So the man gave them his attention, expecting to receive something from them.

6.text: But Peter said, “Silver or gold I do not have, but what I have I give you: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, get up and walk!”

7.text: Taking him by the right hand, Peter helped him up, and at once the man’s feet and ankles were made strong.

8.text: He sprang to his feet and began to walk. Then he went with them into the temple courts, walking and leaping and praising God.

9.text: When all the people saw him walking and praising God,

10.text: they recognized him as the man who used to sit begging at the Beautiful Gate of the temple, and they were filled with wonder and amazement at what had happened to him.

11.text: While the man clung to Peter and John, all the people were astonished and ran to them in the walkway called Solomon’s Colonnade.

12.text: And when Peter saw this, he addressed the people: “Men of Israel, why are you surprised by this? Why do you stare at us as if by our own power or godliness we had made this man walk?

13.text: The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the God of our fathers, has glorified His servant Jesus. You handed Him over and rejected Him before Pilate, even though he had decided to release Him.

14.text: You rejected the Holy and Righteous One and asked that a murderer be released to you.

15.text: You killed the Author of life, but God raised Him from the dead, and we are witnesses of this fact.

16.text: By faith in the name of Jesus, this man whom you see and know has been made strong. It is Jesus’ name and the faith that comes through Him that has given him this complete healing in your presence.

17.text: And now, brothers, I know that you acted in ignorance, as did your leaders.

18.text: But in this way God has fulfilled what He foretold through all the prophets, saying that His Christ would suffer.

19.text: Repent, then, and turn back, so that your sins may be wiped away,

20.text: that times of refreshing may come from the presence of the Lord, and that He may send Jesus, the Christ, who has been appointed for you.

21.text: Heaven must take Him in until the time comes for the restoration of all things, which God announced long ago through His holy prophets.

22.text: For Moses said, ‘The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers. You must listen to Him in everything He tells you.

23.text: Everyone who does not listen to Him will be completely cut off from among his people.’

24.text: Indeed, all the prophets from Samuel on, as many as have spoken, have proclaimed these days.

25.text: And you are sons of the prophets and of the covenant God made with your fathers when He said to Abraham, ‘Through your offspring all the families of the earth will be blessed.’

26.text: When God raised up His Servant, He sent Him first to you to bless you by turning each of you from your wicked ways.”

1.text: While Peter and John were speaking to the people, the priests and the captain of the temple guard and the Sadducees came up to them,

2.text: greatly disturbed that they were teaching the people and proclaiming in Jesus the resurrection of the dead.

3.text: They seized Peter and John, and because it was evening, they put them in custody until the next day.

4.text: But many who heard the message believed, and the number of men grew to about five thousand.

5.text: The next day the rulers, elders, and scribes assembled in Jerusalem,

6.text: along with Annas the high priest, Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and many others from the high priest’s family.

7.text: They had Peter and John brought in and began to question them: “By what power or what name did you do this?”

8.text: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, “Rulers and elders of the people!

9.text: If we are being examined today about a kind service to a man who was lame, to determine how he was healed,

10.text: then let this be known to all of you and to all the people of Israel: It is by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified but whom God raised from the dead, that this man stands before you healed.

11.text: This Jesus is ‘the stone you builders rejected, which has become the cornerstone.’

12.text: Salvation exists in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given to men by which we must be saved.”

13.text: When they saw the boldness of Peter and John and realized that they were unschooled, ordinary men, they marveled and took note that these men had been with Jesus.

14.text: And seeing the man who had been healed standing there with them, they had nothing to say in response.

15.text: So they ordered them to leave the Sanhedrin and then conferred together.

16.text: “What shall we do with these men?” they asked. “It is clear to everyone living in Jerusalem that a remarkable miracle has occurred through them, and we cannot deny it.

17.text: But to keep this message from spreading any further among the people, we must warn them not to speak to anyone in this name.”

18.text: Then they called them in again and commanded them not to speak or teach at all in the name of Jesus.

19.text: But Peter and John replied, “Judge for yourselves whether it is right in God’s sight to listen to you rather than God.

20.text: For we cannot stop speaking about what we have seen and heard.”

21.text: After further threats they let them go. They could not find a way to punish them, because all the people were glorifying God for what had happened.

22.text: For the man who was miraculously healed was over forty years old.

23.text: On their release, Peter and John returned to their own people and reported everything that the chief priests and elders had said to them.

24.text: When the believers heard this, they lifted up their voices to God with one accord. “Sovereign Lord,” they said, “You made the heaven and the earth and the sea and everything in them.

25.text: You spoke by the Holy Spirit through the mouth of Your servant, our father David: ‘Why do the nations rage and the peoples plot in vain?

26.text: The kings of the earth take their stand and the rulers gather together against the Lord and against His Anointed One.’

27.text: In fact, this is the very city where Herod and Pontius Pilate conspired with the Gentiles and the people of Israel against Your holy servant Jesus, whom You anointed.

28.text: They carried out what Your hand and will had decided beforehand would happen.

29.text: And now, Lord, consider their threats, and enable Your servants to speak Your word with complete boldness,

30.text: as You stretch out Your hand to heal and perform signs and wonders through the name of Your holy servant Jesus.”

31.text: After they had prayed, their meeting place was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and spoke the word of God boldly.

32.text: The multitude of believers was one in heart and soul. No one claimed that any of his possessions was his own, but they shared everything they owned.

33.text: With great power the apostles continued to give their testimony about the resurrection of the Lord Jesus. And abundant grace was upon them all.

34.text: There were no needy ones among them, because those who owned lands or houses would sell their property, bring the proceeds from the sales,

35.text: and lay them at the apostles’ feet for distribution to anyone as he had need.

36.text: Joseph, a Levite from Cyprus, whom the apostles called Barnabas (meaning Son of Encouragement),

37.text: sold a field he owned, brought the money, and laid it at the apostles’ feet.

1.text: Now a man named Ananias, together with his wife Sapphira, also sold a piece of property.

2.text: With his wife’s full knowledge, he kept back some of the proceeds for himself, but brought a portion and laid it at the apostles’ feet.

3.text: Then Peter said, “Ananias, how is it that Satan has filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and withhold some of the proceeds from the land?

4.text: Did it not belong to you before it was sold? And after it was sold, was it not at your disposal? How could you conceive such a deed in your heart? You have not lied to men, but to God!”

5.text: On hearing these words, Ananias fell down and died. And great fear came over all who heard what had happened.

6.text: Then the young men stepped forward, wrapped up his body, and carried him out and buried him.

7.text: About three hours later his wife also came in, unaware of what had happened.

8.text: “Tell me,” said Peter, “is this the price you and your husband got for the land?” “Yes,” she answered, “that is the price.”

9.text: “How could you agree to test the Spirit of the Lord?” Peter replied. “Look, the feet of the men who buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out also.”

10.text: At that instant she fell down at his feet and died. Then the young men came in and, finding her dead, carried her out and buried her beside her husband.

11.text: And great fear came over the whole church and all who heard about these events.

12.text: The apostles performed many signs and wonders among the people, and with one accord the believers gathered together in Solomon’s Colonnade.

13.text: Although the people regarded them highly, no one else dared to join them.

14.text: Yet more and more believers were brought to the Lord—large numbers of both men and women.

15.text: As a result, people brought the sick into the streets and laid them on cots and mats, so that at least Peter’s shadow might fall on some of them as he passed by.

16.text: Crowds also gathered from the towns around Jerusalem, bringing the sick and those tormented by unclean spirits, and all of them were healed.

17.text: Then the high priest and all his associates, who belonged to the party of the Sadducees, were filled with jealousy. They went out

18.text: and arrested the apostles and put them in the public jail.

19.text: But during the night an angel of the Lord opened the doors of the jail and brought them out, saying,

20.text: “Go, stand in the temple courts and tell the people the full message of this new life.”

21.text: At daybreak the apostles entered the temple courts as they had been told and began to teach the people. When the high priest and his associates arrived, they convened the Sanhedrin—the full assembly of the elders of Israel—and sent to the jail for the apostles.

22.text: But on arriving at the jail, the officers did not find them there. So they returned with the report:

23.text: “We found the jail securely locked, with the guards posted at the doors; but when we opened them, we found no one inside.”

24.text: When the captain of the temple guard and the chief priests heard this account, they were perplexed as to what was happening.

25.text: Then someone came in and announced, “Look, the men you put in jail are standing in the temple courts teaching the people!”

26.text: At that point, the captain went with the officers and brought the apostles—but not by force, for fear the people would stone them.

27.text: They brought them in and made them stand before the Sanhedrin, where the high priest interrogated them.

28.text: “We gave you strict orders not to teach in this name,” he said. “Yet you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching and are determined to make us responsible for this man’s blood.”

29.text: But Peter and the other apostles replied, “We must obey God rather than men.

30.text: The God of our fathers raised up Jesus, whom you had killed by hanging Him on a tree.

31.text: God exalted Him to His right hand as Prince and Savior, in order to grant repentance and forgiveness of sins to Israel.

32.text: We are witnesses of these things, and so is the Holy Spirit, whom God has given to those who obey Him.”

33.text: When the Council members heard this, they were enraged, and they resolved to put the apostles to death.

34.text: But a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law who was honored by all the people, stood up in the Sanhedrin and ordered that the men be put outside for a short time.

35.text: “Men of Israel,” he said, “consider carefully what you are about to do to these men.

36.text: Some time ago Theudas rose up, claiming to be somebody, and about four hundred men joined him. He was killed, all his followers were dispersed, and it all came to nothing.

37.text: After him, Judas the Galilean appeared in the days of the census and drew away people after him. He too perished, and all his followers were scattered.

38.text: So in the present case I advise you: Leave these men alone. Let them go! For if their purpose or endeavor is of human origin, it will fail.

39.text: But if it is from God, you will not be able to stop them. You may even find yourselves fighting against God.”

40.text: At this, they yielded to Gamaliel. They called the apostles in and had them flogged. Then they ordered them not to speak in the name of Jesus, and released them.

41.text: The apostles left the Sanhedrin, rejoicing that they had been counted worthy of suffering disgrace for the Name.

42.text: Every day, in the temple courts and from house to house, they did not stop teaching and proclaiming the good news that Jesus is the Christ.

1.text: In those days when the disciples were increasing in number, the Grecian Jews among them began to grumble against the Hebraic Jews because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution of food.

2.text: So the Twelve summoned all the disciples and said, “It is unacceptable for us to neglect the word of God in order to wait on tables.

3.text: Therefore, brothers, select from among you seven men confirmed to be full of the Spirit and wisdom. We will assign this responsibility to them

4.text: and will devote ourselves to prayer and to the ministry of the word.”

5.text: This proposal pleased the whole group. They chose Stephen, a man full of faith and of the Holy Spirit, as well as Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas from Antioch, a convert to Judaism.

6.text: They presented these seven to the apostles, who prayed and laid their hands on them.

7.text: So the word of God continued to spread. The number of disciples in Jerusalem grew rapidly, and a great number of priests became obedient to the faith.

8.text: Now Stephen, who was full of grace and power, was performing great wonders and signs among the people.

9.text: But resistance arose from what was called the Synagogue of the Freedmen, including Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and men from the provinces of Cilicia and Asia. They disputed with Stephen,

10.text: but they could not stand up to his wisdom or the Spirit by whom he spoke.

11.text: Then they prompted some men to say, “We heard Stephen speak words of blasphemy against Moses and against God.”

12.text: So they stirred up the people, elders, and scribes and confronted Stephen. They seized him and brought him before the Sanhedrin,

13.text: where they presented false witnesses who said, “This man never stops speaking against this holy place and against the law.

14.text: For we have heard him say that Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs that Moses handed down to us.”

15.text: All who were sitting in the Sanhedrin looked intently at Stephen, and they saw that his face was like the face of an angel.

1.text: Then the high priest asked Stephen, “Are these charges true?”

2.text: And Stephen declared: “Brothers and fathers, listen to me! The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham while he was still in Mesopotamia, before he lived in Haran,

3.text: and told him, ‘Leave your country and your kindred and go to the land I will show you.’

4.text: So Abraham left the land of the Chaldeans and settled in Haran. After his father died, God brought him out of that place and into this land where you are now living.

5.text: He gave him no inheritance here, not even a foot of ground. But God promised to give possession of the land to Abraham and his descendants, even though he did not yet have a child.

6.text: God told him that his descendants would be foreigners in a strange land, and that they would be enslaved and mistreated four hundred years.

7.text: ‘But I will punish the nation that enslaves them,’ God said, ‘and afterward they will come forth and worship Me in this place.’

8.text: Then God gave Abraham the covenant of circumcision, and Abraham became the father of Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day. And Isaac became the father of Jacob, and Jacob of the twelve patriarchs.

9.text: Because the patriarchs were jealous of Joseph, they sold him as a slave into Egypt. But God was with him

10.text: and rescued him from all his troubles. He granted Joseph favor and wisdom in the sight of Pharaoh king of Egypt, who appointed him ruler over Egypt and all his household.

11.text: Then famine and great suffering swept across Egypt and Canaan, and our fathers could not find food.

12.text: When Jacob heard that there was grain in Egypt, he sent our fathers on their first visit.

13.text: On their second visit, Joseph revealed his identity to his brothers, and his family became known to Pharaoh.

14.text: Then Joseph sent for his father Jacob and all his relatives, seventy-five in all.

15.text: So Jacob went down to Egypt, where he and our fathers died.

16.text: Their bones were carried back to Shechem and placed in the tomb that Abraham had bought from the sons of Hamor at Shechem for a price he paid in silver.

17.text: As the time drew near for God to fulfill His promise to Abraham, our people in Egypt increased greatly in number.

18.text: Then another king, who knew nothing of Joseph, arose over Egypt.

19.text: He exploited our people and oppressed our fathers, forcing them to abandon their infants so they would die.

20.text: At that time Moses was born, and he was beautiful in the sight of God. For three months he was nurtured in his father’s house.

21.text: When he was set outside, Pharaoh’s daughter took him and brought him up as her own son.

22.text: So Moses was educated in all the wisdom of the Egyptians and was powerful in speech and action.

23.text: When Moses was forty years old, he decided to visit his brothers, the children of Israel.

24.text: And when he saw one of them being mistreated, Moses went to his defense and avenged him by striking down the Egyptian who was oppressing him.

25.text: He assumed his brothers would understand that God was using him to deliver them, but they did not.

26.text: The next day he came upon two Israelites who were fighting, and he tried to reconcile them, saying, ‘Men, you are brothers. Why are you mistreating each other?’

27.text: But the man who was abusing his neighbor pushed Moses aside and said, ‘Who made you ruler and judge over us?

28.text: Do you want to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?’

29.text: At this remark, Moses fled to the land of Midian, where he lived as a foreigner and had two sons.

30.text: After forty years had passed, an angel appeared to Moses in the flames of a burning bush in the desert near Mount Sinai.

31.text: When Moses saw it, he marveled at the sight. As he approached to look more closely, the voice of the Lord came to him:

32.text: ‘I am the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses trembled with fear and did not dare to look.

33.text: Then the Lord said to him, ‘Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.

34.text: I have indeed seen the oppression of My people in Egypt. I have heard their groaning and have come down to deliver them. Now come, I will send you back to Egypt.’

35.text: This Moses, whom they had rejected with the words, ‘Who made you ruler and judge?’ is the one whom God sent to be their ruler and redeemer through the angel who appeared to him in the bush.

36.text: He led them out and performed wonders and signs in the land of Egypt, at the Red Sea, and for forty years in the wilderness.

37.text: This is the same Moses who told the Israelites, ‘God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers.’

38.text: He was in the assembly in the wilderness with the angel who spoke to him on Mount Sinai, and with our fathers. And he received living words to pass on to us.

39.text: But our fathers refused to obey him. Instead, they rejected him and in their hearts turned back to Egypt.

40.text: They said to Aaron, ‘Make us gods who will go before us! As for this Moses who led us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’

41.text: At that time they made a calf and offered a sacrifice to the idol, rejoicing in the works of their hands.

42.text: But God turned away from them and gave them over to the worship of the host of heaven, as it is written in the book of the prophets: ‘Did you bring Me sacrifices and offerings forty years in the wilderness, O house of Israel?

43.text: You have taken along the tabernacle of Molech and the star of your god Rephan, the idols you made to worship. Therefore I will send you into exile beyond Babylon.’

44.text: Our fathers had the tabernacle of the Testimony with them in the wilderness. It was constructed exactly as God had directed Moses, according to the pattern he had seen.

45.text: And our fathers who received it brought it in with Joshua when they dispossessed the nations God drove out before them. It remained until the time of David,

46.text: who found favor in the sight of God and asked to provide a dwelling place for the God of Jacob.

47.text: But it was Solomon who built the house for Him.

48.text: However, the Most High does not dwell in houses made by human hands. As the prophet says:

49.text: ‘Heaven is My throne and the earth is My footstool. What kind of house will you build for Me, says the Lord, or where will My place of repose be?

50.text: Has not My hand made all these things?’

51.text: You stiff-necked people with uncircumcised hearts and ears! You always resist the Holy Spirit, just as your fathers did.

52.text: Which of the prophets did your fathers fail to persecute? They even killed those who foretold the coming of the Righteous One. And now you are His betrayers and murderers—

53.text: you who received the law ordained by angels, yet have not kept it.”

54.text: On hearing this, the members of the Sanhedrin were enraged, and they gnashed their teeth at him.

55.text: But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, looked intently into heaven and saw the glory of God and Jesus standing at the right hand of God.

56.text: “Look,” he said, “I see heaven open and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God.”

57.text: At this they covered their ears, cried out in a loud voice, and rushed together at him.

58.text: They dragged him out of the city and began to stone him. Meanwhile the witnesses laid their garments at the feet of a young man named Saul.

59.text: While they were stoning him, Stephen appealed, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”

60.text: Falling on his knees, he cried out in a loud voice, “Lord, do not hold this sin against them.” And when he had said this, he fell asleep.

1.text: And Saul was there, giving approval to Stephen’s death. On that day a great persecution broke out against the church in Jerusalem, and all except the apostles were scattered throughout Judea and Samaria.

2.text: God-fearing men buried Stephen and mourned deeply over him.

3.text: But Saul began to destroy the church. Going from house to house, he dragged off men and women and put them in prison.

4.text: Those who had been scattered preached the word wherever they went.

5.text: Philip went down to a city in Samaria and proclaimed the Christ to them.

6.text: The crowds all paid close attention to Philip’s message and to the signs they saw him perform.

7.text: With loud shrieks, unclean spirits came out of many who were possessed, and many of the paralyzed and lame were healed.

8.text: So there was great joy in that city.

9.text: Prior to that time, a man named Simon had practiced sorcery in the city and astounded the people of Samaria. He claimed to be someone great,

10.text: and all the people, from the least to the greatest, heeded his words and said, “This man is the divine power called the Great Power.”

11.text: They paid close attention to him because he had astounded them for a long time with his sorcery.

12.text: But when they believed Philip as he preached the gospel of the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.

13.text: Even Simon himself believed and was baptized. He followed Philip closely and was astounded by the great signs and miracles he observed.

14.text: When the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent Peter and John to them.

15.text: On their arrival, they prayed for them to receive the Holy Spirit.

16.text: For the Holy Spirit had not yet fallen upon any of them; they had simply been baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus.

17.text: Then Peter and John laid their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.

18.text: When Simon saw that the Spirit was given through the laying on of the apostles’ hands, he offered them money.

19.text: “Give me this power as well,” he said, “so that everyone on whom I lay my hands may receive the Holy Spirit.”

20.text: But Peter replied, “May your silver perish with you, because you thought you could buy the gift of God with money!

21.text: You have no part or share in our ministry, because your heart is not right before God.

22.text: Repent, therefore, of your wickedness, and pray to the Lord. Perhaps He will forgive you for the intent of your heart.

23.text: For I see that you are poisoned by bitterness and captive to iniquity.”

24.text: Then Simon answered, “Pray to the Lord for me, so that nothing you have said may happen to me.”

25.text: And after Peter and John had testified and spoken the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, preaching the gospel in many of the Samaritan villages.

26.text: Now an angel of the Lord said to Philip, “Get up and go south to the desert road that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza.”

27.text: So he started out, and on his way he met an Ethiopian eunuch, a court official in charge of the entire treasury of Candace, queen of the Ethiopians. He had gone to Jerusalem to worship,

28.text: and on his return was sitting in his chariot reading Isaiah the prophet.

29.text: The Spirit said to Philip, “Go over to that chariot and stay by it.”

30.text: So Philip ran up and heard the man reading Isaiah the prophet. “Do you understand what you are reading?” Philip asked.

31.text: “How can I,” he said, “unless someone guides me?” And he invited Philip to come up and sit with him.

32.text: The eunuch was reading this passage of Scripture: “He was led like a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb before the shearer is silent, so He did not open His mouth.

33.text: In His humiliation He was deprived of justice. Who can recount His descendants? For His life was removed from the earth.”

34.text: “Tell me,” said the eunuch, “who is the prophet talking about, himself or someone else?”

35.text: Then Philip began with this very Scripture and told him the good news about Jesus.

36.text: As they traveled along the road and came to some water, the eunuch said, “Look, here is water! What is there to prevent me from being baptized?”

38.text: And he gave orders to stop the chariot. Then both Philip and the eunuch went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.

39.text: When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord carried Philip away, and the eunuch saw him no more, but went on his way rejoicing.

40.text: But Philip appeared at Azotus and traveled through that region, preaching the gospel in all the towns until he came to Caesarea.

1.text: Meanwhile, Saul was still breathing out murderous threats against the disciples of the Lord. He approached the high priest

2.text: and requested letters to the synagogues in Damascus, so that if he found any men or women belonging to the Way, he could bring them as prisoners to Jerusalem.

3.text: As Saul drew near to Damascus on his journey, suddenly a light from heaven flashed around him.

4.text: He fell to the ground and heard a voice say to him, “Saul, Saul, why do you persecute Me?”

5.text: “Who are You, Lord?” Saul asked. “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting,” He replied.

6.text: “Now get up and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do.”

7.text: The men traveling with Saul stood there speechless. They heard the voice but did not see anyone.

8.text: Saul got up from the ground, but when he opened his eyes he could not see a thing. So they led him by the hand into Damascus.

9.text: For three days he was without sight, and he did not eat or drink anything.

10.text: In Damascus there was a disciple named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a vision, “Ananias!” “Here I am, Lord,” he answered.

11.text: “Get up!” the Lord told him. “Go to the house of Judas on Straight Street and ask for a man from Tarsus named Saul, for he is praying.

12.text: In a vision he has seen a man named Ananias come and place his hands on him to restore his sight.”

13.text: But Ananias answered, “Lord, many people have told me about this man and all the harm he has done to Your saints in Jerusalem.

14.text: And now he is here with authority from the chief priests to arrest all who call on Your name.”

15.text: “Go!” said the Lord. “This man is My chosen instrument to carry My name before the Gentiles and their kings, and before the people of Israel.

16.text: I will show him how much he must suffer for My name.”

17.text: So Ananias went to the house, and when he arrived, he placed his hands on Saul. “Brother Saul,” he said, “the Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you were coming here, has sent me so that you may see again and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”

18.text: At that instant, something like scales fell from Saul’s eyes, and his sight was restored. He got up and was baptized,

19.text: and after taking some food, he regained his strength. And he spent several days with the disciples in Damascus.

20.text: Saul promptly began to proclaim Jesus in the synagogues, declaring, “He is the Son of God.”

21.text: All who heard him were astounded and asked, “Isn’t this the man who wreaked havoc in Jerusalem on those who call on this name? And hasn’t he come here to take them as prisoners to the chief priests?”

22.text: But Saul was empowered all the more, and he confounded the Jews living in Damascus by proving that Jesus is the Christ.

23.text: After many days had passed, the Jews conspired to kill him,

24.text: but Saul learned of their plot. Day and night they watched the city gates in order to kill him.

25.text: One night, however, his disciples took him and lowered him in a basket through a window in the wall.

26.text: When Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he tried to join the disciples, but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was a disciple.

27.text: Then Barnabas brought him to the apostles and described how Saul had seen the Lord, who had spoken to him on the road to Damascus, and how Saul had spoken boldly in that city in the name of Jesus.

28.text: So Saul stayed with them, moving about freely in Jerusalem and speaking boldly in the name of the Lord.

29.text: He talked and debated with the Grecian Jews, but they tried to kill him.

30.text: When the brothers learned of this, they took him down to Caesarea and sent him off to Tarsus.

31.text: Then the church throughout Judea, Galilee, and Samaria experienced a time of peace. It grew in strength and numbers, living in the fear of the Lord and the encouragement of the Holy Spirit.

32.text: As Peter traveled throughout the area, he went to visit the saints in Lydda.

33.text: There he found a man named Aeneas who had been paralyzed and bedridden for eight years.

34.text: “Aeneas,” Peter said to him, “Jesus Christ heals you! Get up and put away your mat.” Immediately Aeneas got up,

35.text: and all who lived in Lydda and Sharon saw him and turned to the Lord.

36.text: In Joppa there was a disciple named Tabitha (which is translated as Dorcas), who was always occupied with works of kindness and charity.

37.text: At that time, however, she became sick and died, and her body was washed and placed in an upper room.

38.text: Since Lydda was near Joppa, the disciples, hearing that Peter was there, sent two men to urge him, “Come to us without delay.”

39.text: So Peter got up and went with them. On his arrival, they took him to the upper room. All the widows stood around him, weeping and showing him the tunics and other clothing that Dorcas had made while she was still with them.

40.text: Then Peter sent them all out of the room. He knelt down and prayed, and turning toward her body, he said, “Tabitha, get up!” She opened her eyes, and seeing Peter, she sat up.

41.text: Peter took her by the hand and helped her up. Then he called the saints and widows and presented her to them alive.

42.text: This became known all over Joppa, and many people believed in the Lord.

43.text: And Peter stayed for several days in Joppa with a tanner named Simon.

1.text: At Caesarea there was a man named Cornelius, a centurion in what was called the Italian Regiment.

2.text: He and all his household were devout and God-fearing. He gave generously to the people and prayed to God regularly.

3.text: One day at about the ninth hour, he had a clear vision of an angel of God who came to him and said, “Cornelius!”

4.text: Cornelius stared at him in fear and asked, “What is it, Lord?” The angel answered, “Your prayers and gifts to the poor have ascended as a memorial offering before God.

5.text: Now send men to Joppa to call for a man named Simon who is called Peter.

6.text: He is staying with Simon the tanner, whose house is by the sea.”

7.text: When the angel who spoke to him had gone, Cornelius called two of his servants and a devout soldier from among his attendants.

8.text: He explained what had happened and sent them to Joppa.

9.text: The next day at about the sixth hour, as the men were approaching the city on their journey, Peter went up on the roof to pray.

10.text: He became hungry and wanted something to eat, but while the meal was being prepared, he fell into a trance.

11.text: He saw heaven open and something like a large sheet being let down to earth by its four corners.

12.text: It contained all kinds of four-footed animals and reptiles of the earth, as well as birds of the air.

13.text: Then a voice said to him: “Get up, Peter, kill and eat!”

14.text: “No, Lord!” Peter answered. “I have never eaten anything impure or unclean.”

15.text: The voice spoke to him a second time: “Do not call anything impure that God has made clean.”

16.text: This happened three times, and all at once the sheet was taken back up into heaven.

17.text: While Peter was puzzling over the meaning of the vision, the men sent by Cornelius found Simon’s house and approached the gate.

18.text: They called out to ask if Simon called Peter was staying there.

19.text: As Peter continued to reflect on the vision, the Spirit said to him, “Behold, three men are looking for you.

20.text: So get up! Go downstairs and accompany them without hesitation, because I have sent them.”

21.text: So Peter went down to the men and said, “Here am I, the one you are looking for. Why have you come?”

22.text: “Cornelius the centurion has sent us,” they said. “He is a righteous and God-fearing man with a good reputation among the whole Jewish nation. A holy angel instructed him to request your presence in his home so he could hear a message from you.”

23.text: So Peter invited them in as his guests. And the next day he got ready and went with them, accompanied by some of the brothers from Joppa.

24.text: The following day he arrived in Caesarea, where Cornelius was expecting them and had called together his relatives and close friends.

25.text: As Peter was about to enter, Cornelius met him and fell at his feet to worship him.

26.text: But Peter helped him up. “Stand up,” he said, “I am only a man myself.”

27.text: As Peter talked with him, he went inside and found many people gathered together.

28.text: He said to them, “You know how unlawful it is for a Jew to associate with a foreigner or visit him. But God has shown me that I should not call any man impure or unclean.

29.text: So when I was invited, I came without objection. I ask, then, why have you sent for me?”

30.text: Cornelius answered: “Four days ago I was in my house praying at this, the ninth hour. Suddenly a man in radiant clothing stood before me

31.text: and said, ‘Cornelius, your prayer has been heard, and your gifts to the poor have been remembered before God.

32.text: Therefore send to Joppa for Simon, who is called Peter. He is a guest in the home of Simon the tanner, by the sea.’

33.text: So I sent for you immediately, and you were kind enough to come. Now then, we are all here in the presence of God to listen to everything the Lord has instructed you to tell us.”

34.text: Then Peter began to speak: “I now truly understand that God does not show favoritism,

35.text: but welcomes those from every nation who fear Him and do what is right.

36.text: He has sent this message to the people of Israel, proclaiming the gospel of peace through Jesus Christ, who is Lord of all.

37.text: You yourselves know what has happened throughout Judea, beginning in Galilee with the baptism that John proclaimed:

38.text: how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and with power, and how Jesus went around doing good and healing all who were oppressed by the devil, because God was with Him.

39.text: We are witnesses of all that He did, both in the land of the Jews and in Jerusalem. And although they put Him to death by hanging Him on a tree,

40.text: God raised Him up on the third day and caused Him to be seen—

41.text: not by all the people, but by the witnesses God had chosen beforehand, by us who ate and drank with Him after He rose from the dead.

42.text: And He commanded us to preach to the people and to testify that He is the One appointed by God to judge the living and the dead.

43.text: All the prophets testify about Him that everyone who believes in Him receives forgiveness of sins through His name.”

44.text: While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell upon all who heard his message.

45.text: All the circumcised believers who had accompanied Peter were astounded that the gift of the Holy Spirit had been poured out even on the Gentiles.

46.text: For they heard them speaking in tongues and exalting God. Then Peter said,

47.text: “Can anyone withhold the water to baptize these people? They have received the Holy Spirit just as we have!”

48.text: So he ordered that they be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Then they asked him to stay for a few days.

1.text: The apostles and brothers throughout Judea soon heard that the Gentiles also had received the word of God.

2.text: So when Peter went up to Jerusalem, the circumcised believers took issue with him

3.text: and said, “You visited uncircumcised men and ate with them.”

4.text: But Peter began and explained to them the whole sequence of events:

5.text: “I was in the city of Joppa praying, and in a trance I saw a vision of something like a large sheet being let down from heaven by its four corners, and it came right down to me.

6.text: I looked at it closely and saw four-footed animals of the earth, wild beasts, reptiles, and birds of the air.

7.text: Then I heard a voice saying to me, ‘Get up, Peter, kill and eat.’

8.text: ‘No, Lord,’ I said, ‘for nothing impure or unclean has ever entered my mouth.’

9.text: But the voice spoke from heaven a second time, ‘Do not call anything impure that God has made clean.’

10.text: This happened three times, and everything was drawn back up into heaven.

11.text: Just then three men sent to me from Caesarea stopped at the house where I was staying.

12.text: The Spirit told me to accompany them without hesitation. These six brothers also went with me, and we entered the man’s home.

13.text: He told us how he had seen an angel standing in his house and saying, ‘Send to Joppa for Simon who is called Peter.

14.text: He will convey to you a message by which you and all your household will be saved.’

15.text: As I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell upon them, just as He had fallen upon us at the beginning.

16.text: Then I remembered the word of the Lord, how He said, ‘John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.’

17.text: So if God gave them the same gift He gave us who believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I to hinder the work of God?”

18.text: When they heard this, they had no further objections, and they glorified God, saying, “So then, God has granted even the Gentiles repentance unto life.”

19.text: Meanwhile those scattered by the persecution that began with Stephen traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, speaking the message only to Jews.

20.text: But some of them, men from Cyprus and Cyrene, went to Antioch and began speaking to the Greeks as well, proclaiming the good news about the Lord Jesus.

21.text: The hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number of people believed and turned to the Lord.

22.text: When news of this reached the ears of the church in Jerusalem, they sent Barnabas to Antioch.

23.text: When he arrived and saw the grace of God, he rejoiced and encouraged them all to abide in the Lord with all their hearts.

24.text: Barnabas was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and faith, and a great number of people were brought to the Lord.

25.text: Then Barnabas went to Tarsus to look for Saul,

26.text: and when he found him, he brought him back to Antioch. So for a full year they met together with the church and taught large numbers of people. The disciples were first called Christians at Antioch.

27.text: In those days some prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch.

28.text: One of them named Agabus stood up and predicted through the Spirit that a great famine would sweep across the whole world. (This happened under Claudius.)

29.text: So the disciples, each according to his ability, decided to send relief to the brothers living in Judea.

30.text: This they did, sending their gifts to the elders with Barnabas and Saul.

1.text: About that time, King Herod reached out to harm some who belonged to the church.

2.text: He had James, the brother of John, put to death with the sword.

3.text: And seeing that this pleased the Jews, Herod proceeded to seize Peter during the Feast of Unleavened Bread.

4.text: He arrested him and put him in prison, handing him over to be guarded by four squads of four soldiers each. Herod intended to bring him out to the people after the Passover.

5.text: So Peter was kept in prison, but the church was fervently praying to God for him.

6.text: On the night before Herod was to bring him to trial, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains, with sentries standing guard at the entrance to the prison.

7.text: Suddenly an angel of the Lord appeared and a light shone in the cell. He tapped Peter on the side and woke him up, saying, “Get up quickly.” And the chains fell off his wrists.

8.text: “Get dressed and put on your sandals,” said the angel. Peter did so, and the angel told him, “Wrap your cloak around you and follow me.”

9.text: So Peter followed him out, but he was unaware that what the angel was doing was real. He thought he was only seeing a vision.

10.text: They passed the first and second guards and came to the iron gate leading to the city, which opened for them by itself. When they had gone outside and walked the length of one block, the angel suddenly left him.

11.text: Then Peter came to himself and said, “Now I know for sure that the Lord has sent His angel and rescued me from Herod’s grasp and from everything the Jewish people were anticipating.”

12.text: And when he had realized this, he went to the house of Mary the mother of John, also called Mark, where many people had gathered together and were praying.

13.text: He knocked at the outer gate, and a servant girl named Rhoda came to answer it.

14.text: When she recognized Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed that she forgot to open the gate, but ran inside and announced, “Peter is standing at the gate!”

15.text: “You are out of your mind,” they told her. But when she kept insisting it was so, they said, “It must be his angel.”

16.text: But Peter kept on knocking, and when they opened the door and saw him, they were astounded.

17.text: Peter motioned with his hand for silence, and he described how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. “Send word to James and to the brothers,” he said, and he left for another place.

18.text: At daybreak there was no small commotion among the soldiers as to what had become of Peter.

19.text: After Herod had searched for him unsuccessfully, he examined the guards and ordered that they be executed. Then he went down from Judea to Caesarea and spent some time there.

20.text: Now Herod was in a furious dispute with the people of Tyre and Sidon, and they convened before him. Having secured the support of Blastus, the king’s chamberlain, they asked for peace, because their region depended on the king’s country for food.

21.text: On the appointed day, Herod donned his royal robes, sat on his throne, and addressed the people.

22.text: And they began to shout, “This is the voice of a god, not a man!”

23.text: Immediately, because Herod did not give glory to God, an angel of the Lord struck him down, and he was eaten by worms and died.

24.text: But the word of God continued to spread and multiply.

25.text: When Barnabas and Saul had fulfilled their mission to Jerusalem, they returned, bringing with them John, also called Mark.

1.text: Now in the church at Antioch there were prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen (who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch), and Saul.

2.text: While they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, “Set apart for Me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them.”

3.text: And after they had fasted and prayed, they laid their hands on them and sent them off.

4.text: So Barnabas and Saul, sent forth by the Holy Spirit, went down to Seleucia and sailed from there to Cyprus.

5.text: When they arrived at Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the Jewish synagogues. And John was with them as their helper.

6.text: They traveled through the whole island as far as Paphos, where they found a Jewish sorcerer and false prophet named Bar-Jesus,

7.text: an attendant of the proconsul, Sergius Paulus. The proconsul, a man of intelligence, summoned Barnabas and Saul because he wanted to hear the word of God.

8.text: But Elymas the sorcerer (for that is what his name means) opposed them and tried to turn the proconsul from the faith.

9.text: Then Saul, who was also called Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, looked directly at Elymas

10.text: and said, “O child of the devil and enemy of all righteousness, you are full of all kinds of deceit and trickery! Will you never stop perverting the straight ways of the Lord?

11.text: Now look, the hand of the Lord is against you, and for a time you will be blind and unable to see the light of the sun.” Immediately mist and darkness came over him, and he groped about, seeking someone to lead him by the hand.

12.text: When the proconsul saw what had happened, he believed, for he was astonished at the teaching about the Lord.

13.text: After setting sail from Paphos, Paul and his companions came to Perga in Pamphylia, where John left them to return to Jerusalem.

14.text: And from Perga, they traveled inland to Pisidian Antioch, where they entered the synagogue on the Sabbath and sat down.

15.text: After the reading from the Law and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent word to them: “Brothers, if you have a word of encouragement for the people, please speak.”

16.text: Paul stood up, motioned with his hand, and began to speak: “Men of Israel and you Gentiles who fear God, listen to me!

17.text: The God of the people of Israel chose our fathers. He made them into a great people during their stay in Egypt, and with an uplifted arm He led them out of that land.

18.text: He endured their conduct for about forty years in the wilderness.

19.text: And having vanquished seven nations in Canaan, He gave their land to His people as an inheritance.

20.text: All this took about 450 years. After this, God gave them judges until the time of Samuel the prophet.

21.text: Then the people asked for a king, and God gave them Saul son of Kish, from the tribe of Benjamin, who ruled forty years.

22.text: After removing Saul, He raised up David as their king and testified about him: ‘I have found David son of Jesse a man after My own heart; he will carry out My will in its entirety.’

23.text: From the descendants of this man, God has brought to Israel the Savior Jesus, as He promised.

24.text: Before the arrival of Jesus, John preached a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.

25.text: As John was completing his course, he said, ‘Who do you suppose I am? I am not that One. But there is One coming after me whose sandals I am not worthy to untie.’

26.text: Brothers, children of Abraham, and you Gentiles who fear God, it is to us that this message of salvation has been sent.

27.text: The people of Jerusalem and their rulers did not recognize Jesus, yet in condemning Him they fulfilled the words of the prophets that are read every Sabbath.

28.text: And though they found no ground for a death sentence, they asked Pilate to have Him executed.

29.text: When they had carried out all that was written about Him, they took Him down from the tree and laid Him in a tomb.

30.text: But God raised Him from the dead,

31.text: and for many days He was seen by those who had accompanied Him from Galilee to Jerusalem. They are now His witnesses to our people.

32.text: And now we proclaim to you the good news: What God promised our fathers

33.text: He has fulfilled for us, their children, by raising up Jesus. As it is written in the second Psalm: ‘You are My Son; today I have become Your Father.’

34.text: In fact, God raised Him from the dead, never to see decay. As He has said: ‘I will give you the holy and sure blessings promised to David.’

35.text: So also, He says in another Psalm: ‘You will not let Your Holy One see decay.’

36.text: For when David had served God’s purpose in his own generation, he fell asleep. His body was buried with his fathers and saw decay.

37.text: But the One whom God raised from the dead did not see decay.

38.text: Therefore let it be known to you, brothers, that through Jesus the forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you.

39.text: Through Him everyone who believes is justified from everything from which you could not be justified by the law of Moses.

40.text: Watch out, then, that what was spoken by the prophets does not happen to you:

41.text: ‘Look, you scoffers, wonder and perish! For I am doing a work in your days that you would never believe, even if someone told you.’”

42.text: As Paul and Barnabas were leaving the synagogue, the people urged them to continue this message on the next Sabbath.

43.text: After the synagogue was dismissed, many of the Jews and devout converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas, who spoke to them and urged them to continue in the grace of God.

44.text: On the following Sabbath, nearly the whole city gathered to hear the word of the Lord.

45.text: But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with jealousy, and they blasphemously contradicted what Paul was saying.

46.text: Then Paul and Barnabas answered them boldly: “It was necessary to speak the word of God to you first. But since you reject it and do not consider yourselves worthy of eternal life, we now turn to the Gentiles.

47.text: For this is what the Lord has commanded us: ‘I have made you a light for the Gentiles, to bring salvation to the ends of the earth.’”

48.text: When the Gentiles heard this, they rejoiced and glorified the word of the Lord, and all who were appointed for eternal life believed.

49.text: And the word of the Lord spread throughout that region.

50.text: The Jews, however, incited the religious women of prominence and the leading men of the city. They stirred up persecution against Paul and Barnabas and drove them out of their district.

51.text: So they shook the dust off their feet in protest against them and went to Iconium.

52.text: And the disciples were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.

1.text: At Iconium, Paul and Barnabas went as usual into the Jewish synagogue, where they spoke so well that a great number of Jews and Greeks believed.

2.text: But the unbelieving Jews stirred up the Gentiles and poisoned their minds against the brothers.

3.text: So Paul and Barnabas spent considerable time there, speaking boldly for the Lord, who affirmed the message of His grace by enabling them to perform signs and wonders.

4.text: The people of the city were divided. Some sided with the Jews, and others with the apostles.

5.text: But when the Gentiles and Jews, together with their rulers, set out to mistreat and stone them,

6.text: they found out about it and fled to the Lycaonian cities of Lystra and Derbe and to the surrounding region,

7.text: where they continued to preach the gospel.

8.text: In Lystra there sat a man crippled in his feet, who was lame from birth and had never walked.

9.text: This man was listening to the words of Paul, who looked intently at him and saw that he had faith to be healed.

10.text: In a loud voice Paul called out, “Stand up on your feet!” And the man jumped up and began to walk.

11.text: When the crowds saw what Paul had done, they lifted up their voices in the Lycaonian language: “The gods have come down to us in human form!”

12.text: Barnabas they called Zeus, and Paul they called Hermes, because he was the chief speaker.

13.text: The priest of Zeus, whose temple was just outside the city, brought bulls and wreaths to the city gates, hoping to offer a sacrifice along with the crowds.

14.text: But when the apostles Barnabas and Paul found out about this, they tore their clothes and rushed into the crowd, shouting,

15.text: “Men, why are you doing this? We too are only men, human like you. We are bringing you good news that you should turn from these worthless things to the living God, who made heaven and earth and sea and everything in them.

16.text: In past generations, He let all nations go their own way.

17.text: Yet He has not left Himself without testimony to His goodness: He gives you rain from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling your hearts with food and gladness.”

18.text: Even with these words, Paul and Barnabas could hardly stop the crowds from sacrificing to them.

19.text: Then some Jews arrived from Antioch and Iconium and won over the crowds. They stoned Paul and dragged him outside the city, presuming he was dead.

20.text: But after the disciples had gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city. And the next day he left with Barnabas for Derbe.

21.text: They preached the gospel to that city and made many disciples. Then they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch,

22.text: strengthening the souls of the disciples and encouraging them to continue in the faith. “We must endure many hardships to enter the kingdom of God,” they said.

23.text: Paul and Barnabas appointed elders for them in each church, praying and fasting as they entrusted them to the Lord, in whom they had believed.

24.text: After passing through Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia.

25.text: And when they had spoken the word in Perga, they went down to Attalia.

26.text: From Attalia they sailed to Antioch, where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work they had just completed.

27.text: When they arrived, they gathered the church together and reported all that God had done through them, and how He had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.

28.text: And they spent a long time there with the disciples.

1.text: Then some men came down from Judea and were teaching the brothers, “Unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses, you cannot be saved.”

2.text: And after engaging these men in sharp debate, Paul and Barnabas were appointed, along with some other believers, to go up to Jerusalem to see the apostles and elders about this question.

3.text: Sent on their way by the church, they passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, recounting the conversion of the Gentiles and bringing great joy to all the brothers.

4.text: On their arrival in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church and apostles and elders, to whom they reported all that God had done through them.

5.text: But some believers from the party of the Pharisees stood up and declared, “The Gentiles must be circumcised and required to obey the law of Moses.”

6.text: So the apostles and elders met to look into this matter.

7.text: After much discussion, Peter got up and said to them, “Brothers, you know that in the early days God made a choice among you that the Gentiles would hear from my lips the message of the gospel and believe.

8.text: And God, who knows the heart, showed His approval by giving the Holy Spirit to them, just as He did to us.

9.text: He made no distinction between us and them, for He cleansed their hearts by faith.

10.text: Now then, why do you test God by placing on the necks of the disciples a yoke that neither we nor our fathers have been able to bear?

11.text: On the contrary, we believe it is through the grace of the Lord Jesus that we are saved, just as they are.”

12.text: The whole assembly fell silent as they listened to Barnabas and Paul describing the signs and wonders God had done among the Gentiles through them.

13.text: When they had finished speaking, James declared, “Brothers, listen to me!

14.text: Simon has told us how God first visited the Gentiles to take from them a people to be His own.

15.text: The words of the prophets agree with this, as it is written:

16.text: ‘After this I will return and rebuild the fallen tent of David. Its ruins I will rebuild, and I will restore it,

17.text: so that the remnant of men may seek the Lord, and all the Gentiles who are called by My name, says the Lord who does these things

18.text: that have been known for ages.’

19.text: It is my judgment, therefore, that we should not cause trouble for the Gentiles who are turning to God.

20.text: Instead, we should write and tell them to abstain from food polluted by idols, from sexual immorality, from the meat of strangled animals, and from blood.

21.text: For Moses has been proclaimed in every city from ancient times and is read in the synagogues on every Sabbath.”

22.text: Then the apostles and elders, with the whole church, decided to select men from among them to send to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas called Barsabbas and Silas, two leaders among the brothers,

23.text: and sent them with this letter: The apostles and the elders, your brothers, To the brothers among the Gentiles in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia: Greetings.

24.text: It has come to our attention that some went out from us without our authorization and unsettled you, troubling your minds by what they said.

25.text: So we all agreed to choose men to send to you along with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,

26.text: men who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

27.text: Therefore we are sending Judas and Silas to tell you in person the same things we are writing.

28.text: It seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us not to burden you with anything beyond these essential requirements:

29.text: You must abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual immorality. You will do well to avoid these things. Farewell.

30.text: So the men were sent off and went down to Antioch, where they assembled the congregation and delivered the letter.

31.text: When the people read it, they rejoiced at its encouraging message.

32.text: Judas and Silas, who themselves were prophets, said much to encourage and strengthen the brothers.

33.text: After spending some time there, they were sent off by the brothers in peace to return to those who had sent them.

35.text: But Paul and Barnabas remained at Antioch, along with many others, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord.

36.text: Some time later Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us go back and visit the brothers in every town where we proclaimed the word of the Lord, to see how they are doing.”

37.text: Barnabas wanted to take John, also called Mark.

38.text: But Paul thought it best not to take him, because he had deserted them in Pamphylia and had not accompanied them in the work.

39.text: Their disagreement was so sharp that they parted company. Barnabas took Mark and sailed for Cyprus,

40.text: but Paul chose Silas and left, commended by the brothers to the grace of the Lord.

41.text: And he traveled through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.

1.text: Paul came to Derbe and then to Lystra, where he found a disciple named Timothy, the son of a believing Jewish woman and a Greek father.

2.text: The brothers in Lystra and Iconium spoke well of him.

3.text: Paul wanted Timothy to accompany him, so he took him and circumcised him on account of the Jews in that area, for they all knew that his father was a Greek.

4.text: As they went from town to town, they delivered the decisions handed down by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem for the people to obey.

5.text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith and grew daily in numbers.

6.text: After the Holy Spirit had prevented them from speaking the word in the province of Asia, they traveled through the region of Phrygia and Galatia.

7.text: And when they came to the border of Mysia, they tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus would not permit them.

8.text: So they passed by Mysia and went down to Troas.

9.text: During the night, Paul had a vision of a man of Macedonia standing and pleading with him, “Come over to Macedonia and help us.”

10.text: As soon as Paul had seen the vision, we got ready to leave for Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the gospel to them.

11.text: We sailed from Troas straight to Samothrace, and the following day on to Neapolis.

12.text: From there we went to the Roman colony of Philippi, the leading city of that district of Macedonia. And we stayed there several days.

13.text: On the Sabbath we went outside the city gate along the river, where it was customary to find a place of prayer. After sitting down, we spoke to the women who had gathered there.

14.text: Among those listening was a woman named Lydia, a dealer in purple cloth from the city of Thyatira, who was a worshiper of God. The Lord opened her heart to respond to Paul’s message.

15.text: And when she and her household had been baptized, she urged us, “If you consider me a believer in the Lord, come and stay at my house.” And she persuaded us.

16.text: One day as we were going to the place of prayer, we were met by a slave girl with a spirit of divination, who earned a large income for her masters by fortune-telling.

17.text: This girl followed Paul and the rest of us, shouting, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who are proclaiming to you the way of salvation!”

18.text: She continued this for many days. Eventually Paul grew so aggravated that he turned and said to the spirit, “In the name of Jesus Christ I command you to come out of her!” And the spirit left her at that very moment.

19.text: When the girl’s owners saw that their hope of making money was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them before the authorities in the marketplace.

20.text: They brought them to the magistrates and said, “These men are Jews and are throwing our city into turmoil

21.text: by promoting customs that are unlawful for us Romans to adopt or practice.”

22.text: The crowd joined in the attack against Paul and Silas, and the magistrates ordered that they be stripped and beaten with rods.

23.text: And after striking them with many blows, they threw them into prison and ordered the jailer to guard them securely.

24.text: On receiving this order, he placed them in the inner cell and fastened their feet in the stocks.

25.text: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.

26.text: Suddenly a strong earthquake shook the foundations of the prison. At once all the doors flew open and everyone’s chains came loose.

27.text: When the jailer woke up and saw the prison doors open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, presuming that the prisoners had escaped.

28.text: But Paul called out in a loud voice, “Do not harm yourself! We are all here!”

29.text: Calling for lights, the jailer rushed in and fell trembling before Paul and Silas.

30.text: Then he brought them out and asked, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”

31.text: They replied, “Believe in the Lord Jesus and you will be saved, you and your household.”

32.text: Then Paul and Silas spoke the word of the Lord to him and to everyone in his house.

33.text: At that hour of the night, the jailer took them and washed their wounds. And without delay, he and all his household were baptized.

34.text: Then he brought them into his home and set a meal before them. So he and all his household rejoiced that they had come to believe in God.

35.text: When daylight came, the magistrates sent their officers with the order: “Release those men.”

36.text: The jailer informed Paul: “The magistrates have sent orders to release you. Now you may go on your way in peace.”

37.text: But Paul said to the officers, “They beat us publicly without a trial and threw us into prison, even though we are Roman citizens. And now do they want to send us away secretly? Absolutely not! Let them come themselves and escort us out!”

38.text: So the officers relayed this message to the magistrates, who were alarmed to hear that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.

39.text: They came to appease them and led them out, requesting that they leave the city.

40.text: After Paul and Silas came out of the prison, they went to Lydia’s house to see the brothers and encourage them. Then they left the city.

1.text: When they had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.

2.text: As was his custom, Paul went into the synagogue, and on three Sabbaths he reasoned with them from the Scriptures,

3.text: explaining and proving that the Christ had to suffer and rise from the dead. “This Jesus I am proclaiming to you is the Christ,” he declared.

4.text: Some of the Jews were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, along with a large number of God-fearing Greeks and quite a few leading women.

5.text: The Jews, however, became jealous. So they brought in some troublemakers from the marketplace, formed a mob, and sent the city into an uproar. They raided Jason’s house in search of Paul and Silas, hoping to bring them out to the people.

6.text: But when they could not find them, they dragged Jason and some other brothers before the city officials, shouting, “These men who have turned the world upside down have now come here,

7.text: and Jason has welcomed them into his home. They are all defying Caesar’s decrees, saying that there is another king, named Jesus!”

8.text: On hearing this, the crowd and city officials were greatly disturbed.

9.text: And they collected bond from Jason and the others and then released them.

10.text: As soon as night had fallen, the brothers sent Paul and Silas away to Berea. On arriving there, they went into the Jewish synagogue.

11.text: Now the Bereans were more noble-minded than the Thessalonians, for they received the message with great eagerness and examined the Scriptures every day to see if these teachings were true.

12.text: As a result, many of them believed, along with quite a few prominent Greek women and men.

13.text: But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that Paul was also proclaiming the word of God in Berea, they went there themselves to incite and agitate the crowds.

14.text: The brothers immediately sent Paul to the coast, but Silas and Timothy remained in Berea.

15.text: Those who escorted Paul brought him to Athens and then returned with instructions for Silas and Timothy to join him as soon as possible.

16.text: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was deeply disturbed in his spirit to see that the city was full of idols.

17.text: So he reasoned in the synagogue with the Jews and God-fearing Gentiles, and in the marketplace with those he met each day.

18.text: Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also began to debate with him. Some of them asked, “What is this babbler trying to say?” Others said, “He seems to be advocating foreign gods.” They said this because Paul was proclaiming the good news of Jesus and the resurrection.

19.text: So they took Paul and brought him to the Areopagus, where they asked him, “May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?

20.text: For you are bringing some strange notions to our ears, and we want to know what they mean.”

21.text: Now all the Athenians and foreigners who lived there spent their time doing nothing more than hearing and articulating new ideas.

22.text: Then Paul stood up in the meeting of the Areopagus and said, “Men of Athens, I see that in every way you are very religious.

23.text: For as I walked around and examined your objects of worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: TO AN UNKNOWN GOD. Therefore what you worship as something unknown, I now proclaim to you.

24.text: The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth and does not live in temples made by human hands.
